CLASSICAL GREEK
STANDARD LEVEL
PAPER 2

Friday 21 May 2010 (morning)

1 hour 30 minutes


Instructions to candidates

 Do not open this examination paper until instructed to do so.
 Answer three questions from two genres only.

Answer all the questions from three passages taken from two genres only.

Genre: Epic

Question 1.   Homer Iliad 6.212–231




              215




              220




              225




              230




      (a)   What do we learn from this passage about       ?                             [3 marks]

      (b)   What was the relationship between Oeneus and Diomedes and between
            Bellerophon and Glaucos?                                                     [4 marks]

      (c)   Scan lines 227–228 (                                           ).            [2 marks]

      (d)   Translate                                                 (lines 230–231).   [3 marks]

      (e)   What amusing comment does Homer make immediately after this passage?         [3 marks]




2210-2954
                                               –3–                M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

Genre: Epic

Question 2.   Homer Iliad 6.279–296



            280




            285




            290




            295




      (a)                             (lines 279–280). Who is speaking here and for
            what immediate purpose?                                                     [3 marks]

      (b)                                                (lines 280–285). What is the
            speaker’s attitude to Paris? What would he like to see happen to Paris?
            Suggest two reasons, not stated here, for his attitude.                     [4 marks]

      (c)   Translate                                            (lines 286–287).       [3 marks]

      (d)   Who was                  (line 290)? How had he contributed to the
            women’s ritual? Why was the reference to     (line 292) significant in
            that context?                                                               [3 marks]

      (e)   Scan lines 294–295                                                          [2 marks]




2210-2954                                                                               Turn over
                                                  –4–                 M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

Genre: Historiography

Question 3.    Thucydides 2.39.1–2




               5




              10




      (a)   What is the purpose of this speech and how was praise of Athens relevant to
            that purpose?                                                                     [2 marks]
		
      (b)   Translate
                                       (lines 1–2).                                           [3 marks]

      (c)   From what two Greek words is                    (line 3) derived? Where was
            it practised?                                                                     [3 marks]


      (d)                                                (lines 12–13). What is Pericles
            claiming that Athenians can do to these people? Why is it significant for his
            basic purpose?                                                                    [3 marks]

      (e)   Choose from this passage two ways in which Pericles claims that the Athenians
            are superior to the Spartans, and comment briefly on each of them. In answering
            this question you may develop points you have made above.                         [4 marks]




2210-2954
                                                  –5–                    M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

Genre: Historiography

Question 4.        Thucydides 2.44.1–3




               5




              10



      (a)   To which group of people is this part of the speech specifically directed?
            Give two other parts of this speech which were, in your opinion, likely to have
            been well or ill received by the original audience.                               [3 marks]

      (b)                                                          (lines 1–2). What is the
            difference between these terms? Explain Pericles’ stated preference.              [3 marks]

      (c)                                            (line 7–8). Explain the poignancy of
            these words.                                                                      [3 marks]

      (d)   Translate                                    (lines 8–10).                        [3 marks]

      (e)                                        (lines 10–11). What is Pericles’
            suggestion here?       Assess how it might have been received by the
            original audience.                                                                [3 marks]




2210-2954                                                                                     Turn over
                                                  –6–                  M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

Genre: Tragedy

Question 5.   Sophocles Oedipus Tyrannus 14–30



                   15




                   20




                   25




                   30


      (a)   Who is speaking these words to whom? What is he trying to achieve?                [3 marks]

      (b)   Give two examples of the effective use of rhetorical devices from this passage
            and explain them.                                                                 [4 marks]

      (c)                                       (lines 25–27). What three examples of
            evidence of blight are mentioned here? You may refer to words treated elsewhere
            in your answers.                                                                  [3 marks]

      (d)   Scan lines 25–26 (                                  ).                            [2 marks]

      (e)   Translate                                                (lines 27–29).           [3 marks]




2210-2954
                                                   –7–                 M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

Genre: Tragedy

Question 6.    Sophocles Oedipus Tyrannus 1132–1154




              1135




              1140




              1145




              1150




      (a)   Explain what the                 knows and does not know, and why the
                       is afraid to reveal what he himself knows.                              [4 marks]

      (b)   Identify three places in this passage (giving the Greek text in each case) where
            Oedipus reveals something of his character.                                        [3 marks]

      (c)   Identify three attempts by the                  to avoid having to tell what
            he knows.                                                                          [3 marks]

      (d)   Scan lines 1151–1152 (                          ).                                 [2 marks]

      (e)   Translate                                            (lines 1153–1154).            [3 marks]

Genre: Comedy

Question 7.   Aristophanes Frogs 193–207




                     195




                     200




                     205




2210-2954
                                                  –9–                 M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

      (a)   Identify the three characters in this passage and explain what each is trying
            to achieve.                                                                       [3 marks]

      (b)   Choose any two moments in this passage, excluding line 204, when the
            contemporary audience would, in your opinion, have laughed, and explain how
            each achieves its effect.                                                         [4 marks]

      (c)   Translate                                          (lines 194–195).               [3 marks]

      (d)                                                (line 204). Explain the rhetorical
            effect of these words. To what does                 refer?                        [3 marks]

      (e)   Scan lines 205–206 (                                 ).                           [2 marks]

Genre: Comedy

Question 8.   Aristophanes Frogs 1379–1392



                   1380




                   1385




                   1390




2210-2954
                                                – 11 –              M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

      (a)   This passage occurs during a competition. Name the contestants and the judge
            and explain how the competition is conducted.                                  [4 marks]

      (b)   Choose from this passage an example illustrating a criterion by which the
            competitors are judged, and comment on its humour.                             [3 marks]

      (c)                    (line 1386). What does this word mean here? Explain the
            humour of its original sense in this context.                                  [3 marks]


      (d)   Scan lines 1388–1389 (                                           ).            [2 marks]


      (e)   Translate                                (lines 1391–1392).                    [3 marks]

Genre: Philosophy

Question 9.    Plato Crito 44c6–e2




                5




               10




               15



      (a)                               (lines 1–2). What was the        to which Crito
            has just referred, and why was it a matter of such concern to Crito but not
            to Socrates?                                                                   [3 marks]

      (b)                                  (line 6). To what do these words refer?
            How does Crito hope to use them to persuade Socrates?                          [3 marks]


      (c)                                          (lines 10–12).   Show how Socrates
            cleverly uses Crito’s words to contradict him.                                 [3 marks]

      (d)   Translate                                       (lines 12–14).                 [3 marks]

      (e)
            (lines 15–16). What is Crito trying to achieve with these words? Show how he
            uses a rhetorical device in an attempt to achieve his goal.                    [3 marks]




2210-2954
                                                      – 13 –              M10/2/GREEK/SP2/ENG/TZ0/XX

Genre: Philosophy

Question 10. Plato Crito 53a8–c5




             5




            10




            15


      (a)        Who are speaking in this passage? What are they trying to achieve, and on what
                 general grounds?                                                                 [3 marks]

      (b)                                                (lines 3–5). According to the
                 speakers here, what three punishments might Socrates’ friends face if they
                 helped him to escape?                                                            [3 marks]

      (c)        On what grounds is it argued that Socrates would risk being a
                                                  (lines 7–8) if he fled to a well
                 run state?                                                                       [3 marks]

      (d)                                                              (line 12). Why do you
                 think these words were placed here? What effect would they be likely to have
                 on Socrates?                                                                     [3 marks]

      (e)        Translate                                             (lines 1–3).               [3 marks]
